00040 #ifndef _physworld_h
00041 #define _physworld_h
00042 
00043 /**
00044  @mainpage Physgame
00045  The Physgame engine is an abstraction layer between less portable, less user friendly, more sophistciated
00046  libraries and the game you want to make. If we do our jobs right this will save time and effort porting
00047  games between a variety of platforms. If you link only against this library, not a single line of your
00048  Standard compliant C++ code should need to change between platforms. At this early stage we are proving the
00049  concept with "Catch!" our first sample game. It Currently runs on Linux and Windows with an Identical
00050  codebase, when we are done with "Catch!" We want it to have one codebase, and downloadable in the Iphone
00051  app store, the Xbox store, on the PS3, on Steam, and in a variety of linux repositories.
00052 
00053  To get the latest news on development checkout: http://gitorious.org/physgame
00054  The wiki Which acts as our current Knowledge base: http://gitorious.org/physgame/pages/Home
00055 
00056  @section Engine Structure
00057   @subpage mainloop1 "Main Loop Flow"
00058 
00059   //@subpage CallbackManager "Call Back Manager"
00060 
00061   //@subpage EventManager "Event Manager"
00062 
00063   //@subpage Actor "Items in the world - Actor Class"
00064 
00065 */
00066

00075 #include <queue>

00079 //forward Declarations so that we do not need #include "physvector.h"
00080 //forward Declarations so that we do not need #include "gamesettings.h"
00081 //Forward declarations to prevent infite loop of includes
00082 class Settings;
00083 class PhysVector3;
00084 class ActorBase;
00085 //Other forward declarations
00086 //forward Declarations so that we do not need #include "SDL.h"
00087 class SDL_Surface;

00089 //forward Declarations so that we do not need #include "btBulletDynamicsCommon.h"
00090 class btAxisSweep3;
00091 class btDefaultCollisionConfiguration;
00092 class btCollisionDispatcher;
00093 class btSequentialImpulseConstraintSolver;
00094 class btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld;

00097 //forward Declarations so that we do not need #include <Ogre.h>
00098 namespace Ogre
00099 {
00100         class Root;
00101         class RenderSystem;
00102         class RenderWindow;
00103     class ResourceGroupManager;
00104         class SceneManager;
00105         class Camera;
00106         class Viewport;

00110 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00111 /// @class PhysWorld
00112 /// @headerfile physworld.h
00113 /// @brief This is the main entry point for the entire library.
00114 /// @details The physworld coordinates and integrates all the underlying subsystems,
00115 /// Currently Ogre3d is used for 3d Graphics, Bullet is used for physics, and
00116 /// SDL is used for user input and window management. Games will need a
00117 /// container for all the playing pieces. It makes sense to tie all of this
00118 /// functionality into one world object.
00119 ///////////////////////////////////////
00120 class PhysWorld
00121 {
00122         private:
00123                 //Physics Items
00124                 PhysVector3* GeographyLowerBounds;
00125                 PhysVector3* GeographyUpperbounds;
00126                 unsigned short int  MaxPhysicsProxies;
00127 
00128                 btAxisSweep3* BulletBroadphase;
00129                 btDefaultCollisionConfiguration* BulletCollisionConfiguration;
00130                 btCollisionDispatcher* BulletDispatcher;
00131                 btSequentialImpulseConstraintSolver* BulletSolver;
00132                 btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* BulletDynamicsWorld;
00133 
00134                 //SDL Objects
00135                 SDL_Surface *SDLscreen;
00136 
00137                 //Ogre objects
00138         Ogre::Root* OgreRoot;
00139         Ogre::RenderSystem* OgreRenderSystem;
00140         Ogre::RenderWindow* OgreGameWindow;
00141         Ogre::ResourceGroupManager* OgreResource;
00142                 Ogre::SceneManager* OgreSceneManager;
00143                 Ogre::Camera* OgreCamera;
00144                 Ogre::Viewport* OgreViewport;
00145 
00146                 //Players settings
00147                 Settings* PlayerSettings;
00148 
00149                 //Try to retrieve ogre settinss
00150                 void LoadOgreSettings();
00151 
00152                 //Manages the windows all the graphics will be drawn to
00153                 void CreateRenderWindow();
00154                 void DestroyRenderWindow();
00155 
00156                 //Used by the constructors
00157                 void Construct(PhysVector3* GeographyLowerBounds, PhysVector3* GeographyUpperbounds, unsigned short int MaxPhysicsProxies);
00158         void TestLogger();
00159         template <class T> void OneLogTest(T Data, string DataType,string Message1 = "Logging and Throwing a ", string Message2 = "Logging a ");
00160 
00161                 //SDL specific Items
00162                 //This function will get all the events from SDL and Sort them into one of two Queues
00163                 void PreProcessSDLEvents();
00164         queue<RawEvent*> SDL_WmEvents;
00165         queue<RawEvent*> SDL_UserInputEvents;
00166 
00167         /// @brief Do Not Use this, This should be treated as an internal function, it is \b subject \b to \b change \b without \b warning and could be \b harmful to overall stability if used incorrectly
00168         /// @warning This should be treated as an internal function, it is \b subject \b to \b change \b without \b warning and could be \b harmful to overall stability if used incorrectly
00169         friend void RenderPhysWorld(PhysWorld *TheWorld);
00170 
00171         public:
00172         /// @brief Descriptive constructor
00173         /// @details This constructor allows for an easier way to define the boundaries for items moving about inside the physworld.
00174         /// @param GeographyLowerBounds The lower limits for the size of the physics simulation
00175         /// @param GeographyUpperbounds The Upper limits for the size of the physics simulation
00176         /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies This is the amount of Adows (Also called Actors or Proxies) allowed in a physics simulation.
00177                 PhysWorld(PhysVector3* GeographyLowerBounds, PhysVector3* GeographyUpperbounds, unsigned short int MaxPhysicsProxies=1024);
00178 
00179         /// @brief Default constructor
00180         /// @details This simply performs the same work as the descriptive constructor with some sane, but small, limits. It will give you a world which expands for 100 units from the Origin, and only allows 10 Adows.
00181                 PhysWorld();
00182 
00183         /// @brief Deconstructor
00184         /// @details This Tears down all the items create by the physworld, and safely frees any graphical resources, we will also delete any Objects passed into the
00185         /// Physworld by pointer. We will not delete any pointers we pass out (like from the Events from the Event manager)
00186                 ~PhysWorld();
00187 
00188                 /// @brief Runtime Event logging Function
00189                 /// @details Be careful with this function, even though it appears to be a template, it does not support every data type. If Physgame is
00190                 /// Compiled as a Shared Object, Dynamic Linked Library, or some other kind of stand alone library It will only support data types
00191                 /// that are called internally, Currently that list includes: string, char, short int, int, long int, unsigned short int, unsigned int
00192                 /// unsigned long int, bool, float, double, long double, wchar_t, size_t, PhysReal, PhysWhole, PhysString, PhysVector3, RawEvent and MetaCode.
00193                 /// If compiled statically it should support any data type which supports output streams.
00194                 /// @param Message This is what will be streamed to the log
00195         template <class T> void Log(T Message);
00196         /// @brief This is the preffered way to throw an exception currently
00197         /// @details This will log the Message, and will throw an exception with the Message included. Currently this supports all the Data
00198         /// type the Log function supports
00199         /// @param Message This will be streamed to the log, then used in a thrown exception.
00200         template <class T> void LogAndThrow(T Message);
00201 
00202         /// @brief This Shows an Engine Generated Configuration Screen
00203         /// @details This could look like and could offer just about any option to the user. It is loosely expected to show Graphical Configuration
00204         /// options, like Vsync and Resolution, But it might ask some really silly stuff. I thnk this would be fine for smaller simpler
00205         /// Which have no other way to configure such things, but any sizable project should develop their own way to expose and manage
00206         /// user settings.
00207         bool ShowSystemSettingDialog();
00208 
00209                 /// @brief This moves the camera relative to the world
00210                 /// @details The parameters really do explain it. This puts the camera at an arbitrary point, pointing at an arbitrary point.
00211         /// @param Position Where should the camera be seated
00212                 /// @param LookAt Point the camera such that this poin is centered on the screen
00213                 void MoveCamera(PhysVector3 Position, PhysVector3 LookAt);
00214 
00215         /// @brief This creates the game window and starts the game.
00216         /// @details Prior to this all of the physics and graphical object containers should have been loaded and prepared for use. There should be
00217         /// minimal delay from the time you call this and the game actually begins.
00218         /// This is also where the Main Loop for the game is housed.
00219         void GameInit();
00220 
00221         /// @brief Performs all the items that would normally be performed during the game loop
00222         /// @details This simply calls: DoMainLoopPhysics, DoMainLoopInputBuffering, DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering, DoMainLoopRender. This is
00223         /// useful for anyone wants to use as little of the existing main loop structure as possible, or does not want to run a certain Items
00224         /// each iteration of the main loop.
00225         void DoMainLoopAllItems();
00226 
00227         /// @brief Increments physics by one step
00228         /// @details Currently one step is about 1/60 of a second. This function is automatically called in the main loop if a Pre-Physics Callback is
00229         /// set. This is the second step in the main loop chain of events. This is where we expect the majority of our collision events to come
00230         /// from although it is concievable that a game could manually insert those manually. This will not delete events it places
00231         /// in the event manager, that is the responsibility of the code that pulls out the event out.
00232         void DoMainLoopPhysics();
00233 
00234         /// @brief Gathers user input from the OS and places events in the event manager
00235         /// @details This this is automatically called during the mainloop if you have set a PreInput callback. This will not delete events it places
00236         /// in the event manager, that is the responsibility of the code that pulls out the event out.
00237                 void DoMainLoopInputBuffering();
00238 
00239                 /// @brief Creates events for each Window manger
00240                 /// @details This gather information from system/windows manager events, such as windows  minimization, maximization, program exit, window hidden
00241                 /// window shown, and a few other similar types of events. This makes events out of the information and places them in the event manager
00242                 /// This will not delete events it places in the event manager, that is the responsibility of the code that pulls out the event out.
00243                 void DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering();
00244 
00245         /// @brief This forces the screen to be re-rendered
00246         /// @details This renders the screen based on the status of all in game actors. This is automatically called in the main loop.
00247                 void DoMainLoopRender();
00248 
00249         /// @brief The adds and Actor to the physworld.
00250         /// @details The takes over for manager an Actor, and makes sure that it's physics status and 3d graphics status are properly handled. Once an
00251         /// actor has been passed into the Physworld using this, the physworld handle deleting it.
00252         /// @param ActorToAdd This is a pointer to the actor to be added
00253         void AddActor(ActorBase* ActorToAdd);
00254 
00255                 /// @brief This is a point to the default Call BackManager
00256         /// @details All the callbacks that the main loop and the rest of physgame use are will be found in the callback manager point to by this.
00257                 PhysWorldCallBackManager* CallBacks;
00258 
00259         /// @brief This is the default pointer to the Event Manager.
00260         /// @details This is the Event manager that all physworld members will place any events into.
00261                 PhysEventManager* Events;
00262 };
00263 #endif
